Title: See the Person, Not the Stereotype

If you only learned about high school from movies, you’d think prom always ends in flames. If you only learned about schizophrenia from movies, you’d think it means villains, split personalities, and danger. I’m here to tell you it’s not like that. I live with schizophrenia, I’m doing well, and I’m asking you to drop the stereotypes and see the person in front of you.

Schizophrenia is a real brain-based condition that affects how someone experiences reality—things like thoughts, perception, and motivation. For some people, that can include hearing or seeing things others don’t, or holding beliefs that don’t match reality. It can also mean feeling drained, unfocused, or less motivated. It’s not a plot twist, and it’s not a character flaw. It’s part of how my brain works—and with support, routines, and treatment, many of us do just fine in school, at work, and in relationships.

Let’s bust a few myths.

Myth one: Schizophrenia means “split personalities.” That’s not true. You’re thinking of another condition entirely. Schizophrenia doesn’t split someone into different people; it can create a split between what the brain is telling you and what’s actually happening. Big difference.

Myth two: People with schizophrenia are dangerous. In reality, most people with schizophrenia are not violent. We’re far more likely to be on the receiving end of violence than to cause it. What increases risk in those sensational headlines is usually things like lack of support or substance use—factors that affect everyone, not just people with schizophrenia. Fear makes great movie scenes but terrible facts.

Myth three: It’s rare and hopeless. Actually, it affects about 1 in 100 people. That means you probably already know someone—maybe you just didn’t realize it. And “hopeless” is the opposite of what recovery looks like. With the right tools—medical care, therapy, routines, and supportive people—many of us graduate, work, date, and pursue goals like anyone else. Progress isn’t always a straight line, but it’s real.

Here’s what my day can look like. I go to class. I joke with friends. I stress about deadlines like everyone else. Sometimes my brain throws me static—extra noise, distracting thoughts, or a wave of low energy. I manage it with strategies: sticking to routines, taking short breaks, double-checking what I’m hearing or thinking, and staying connected with people I trust. None of this makes me scary. It just makes me a person with a system that helps me thrive.

So what do I want from our school? Honestly, it’s simple.

- Watch your words. Calling people “psycho” or “schizo” isn’t funny—it’s lazy. If you mean unpredictable, say unpredictable. If you mean exciting, say exciting. Accuracy is cooler than stigma.
- Be curious, not nosy. If someone opens up, you don’t have to play doctor or detective. Try, “Thanks for telling me—how can I support you?” Respect privacy and take people at their word.
- Don’t debate symptoms. If a friend seems to be hearing or seeing something, you don’t have to argue them out of it. You can ground the moment: “You’re safe. I’m here. Want to step outside or get some water?”
- Challenge the media script. Notice when movies and shows turn people like me into monsters or jokes. Ask, “Whose story is missing?” We can demand better representation.
- Choose inclusion. Invite people to hang out. Offer notes if someone misses class. In group projects, be flexible about roles and communication. Small choices make a big difference.

Maybe you’re thinking, “Why does language matter so much?” Because words build the world we live in. If we use words that treat mental health like a punchline, people stay silent. When we use words that show respect, people get help sooner, recover better, and feel safer being themselves. That helps our whole community.

If you remember one thing from this speech, let it be this: I’m not a stereotype. I’m not a headline. I’m your classmate. Schizophrenia is part of my life, but it doesn’t define my worth, my future, or how I should be treated. The next time you hear a joke, push back. The next time you see a sensational story, question it. And the next time you meet someone living with schizophrenia, start with “Hi,” not with fear.

We can’t control the movies. But we can control our hallway. Let’s make ours a place where people are seen for who they are, not for what someone else decided to fear.

*   Hallucinations (hearing or seeing things that aren't there)

*   Disorganized thinking and speech
*   Negative symptoms, such as apathy or lack of motivation
